content.html:
Finished reading: The Dawn of Everything: A New History of Humanity by David Graeber and David Wengrow üìö

This book is worth reading, as are the critiques of it, especially the responses by Chris Knight, Nancy Lindisfarne, and Jonathan Neale. I would not waste your time with any reviews penned by employees of the American Enterprise Institute.

I‚Äôm glad I finished this book and found it worth engaging with. Graeber and Wengrow present a much more hopeful view of humanity than the other popular titles in the Big Histories genre they are in argument with, including ‚ÄúSapiens‚Äù and ‚ÄúGuns, Germs and Steel‚Äù.
content.value:

This book is worth reading, as are the critiques of it, especially the responses by Chris Knight, Nancy Lindisfarne, and Jonathan Neale. I would not waste your time with any reviews penned by employees of the American Enterprise Institute.

I‚Äôm glad I finished this book and found it worth engaging with. Graeber and Wengrow present a much more hopeful view of humanity than the other popular titles in the Big Histories genre they are in argument with, including ‚ÄúSapiens‚Äù and ‚ÄúGuns, Germs and Steel‚Äù.

content.html:
On the fourth day of Christmas, I am still hoping to capture that warm, inside a Jan Brett picture book feeling.

It hasn‚Äôt been a bad holiday (it is our first as parents, after all), but for the third consecutive year Covid has thrown a couple wrenches into our celebrations.
